repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Second Financial Institutions
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Financial
            Institutions Development Project of Tanzania were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: 1) The privatization of large
            state-owned banks can directly lead to a sustained
            improvement of access to financial services in rural areas;
            2) Building a strong financial infrastructure is essential,
            but progress can be slow and certain reforms may have to be
            sequential; 3) Long-term investment in capacity building of
            regulators is a key success factor for successful project
            implementation, especially with regards to privatizations;
            and 4) Mainstreaming of project implementation contributes
            significantly to strengthening of client capacity and to
            signaling clear lines of authority vis-à-vis the private sector.

Tanzania - Second Financial Institutions

5084641.majtheme: Public sector governance,Rural development,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Second Financial Institutions
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Financial
            Institutions Development Project, is to improve access by
            small savers, and micro entrepreneurs, within a sound, and
            competitive financial system environment. The components
            are: 1) The restructuring, and privatization of major banks,
            will provide considerable management expertise support in
            banking operations, treasury, and micro-finance. Staff
            training, management information systems, and, research, and
            development funding for the micro-finance pilots, will be
            provided. The component will also address bridge
            compensation payments to redundant staff, bond
            re-capitalization to fill financing gaps, and, review
            options for the restructuring, and privatization of
            remaining state-owned banks. 2) The financial infrastructure
            strengthening, will upgrade the technical skills of the
            banking supervision within the Bank of Tanzania, namely,
            strengthening the financial data integrity, through improved
            analytical skills, and, accounting standards. In addition,
            the payments system, Credit Reference Bureau, and, the
            Capital Markets and Securities Authority, will continue to
            be supported, through operational financing. 3) Funding will
            be provided for the establishment, and management - on a
            pilot basis - of the first three years of the Privatization
            Trust, to broaden local private participation.
